content: I began having problems with the story in the second paragraph. "Not since Henry Stimson’s tenure from 1940 to ’45 has a defense secretary been faced to the same degree with simultaneously fighting a war and carrying out far-reaching reforms." What reforms were carried out during WWII? Ending segregation in the armed forces? That happened uner Truman; after the war. Of course the Army Air Corp became thwe Army Air Force; one step closer to an independent branch of the armed forces. At the moment, the Army, Navy and Marine Corps are at war, but the Air Force is not. This is not the fault of the Air Force: it is simply not structured to be in the fights in Iraq and Afghanistan. And since the Air Force is not as involved in the current war as the author would like, we abolish it. That's being very shortsighted. The result is an “up or out” system that demands service members move up the ladder simply to stay in the military. Any soldier passed over for promotion twice must leave or retire. This is one segment of the editorial that makes sence. If a service member is competent at a certain level, they should be able to stay in at that level.

content: Part of the harsh feelings towards the Air Force from the other service branches come from the perception that the USAF wants to control all fixed wing (non-helicopter) aviation and space/satellite assets - a perception which is partially false. There are a couple steps that the USAF could take towards ending this: 1. Turning dedicated Close Air Support assets (in particular the A-10 Warthog) over to the Army/USMC. 2. Take an equal part and share of the warfighting burden from the other 3 services - to include budget cuts if need be so that the soldier/Marine on the ground has ALL needed equipment. Yes, I know that means that some stateside Airman may have to do without their leather massage chair, but sacrifices must be made. 3. Let the other 3 services develop fixed wing aviation and space assets without interference.

content: quote: Originally posted by Migbuster: Dumb Jar-Head.......must have failed to become a piolt/ didn't get promoted fastenought......JMHO. Yup, that was my take on it almost immediately. It is the many layered redundancy of our military that makes it such a befuddling target to potential enemies. The Air Force was moved out of the control of the Army to give it more flexibility, while allowing the Army to focus on the ground war. This need was made evident in both Europe and the Pacific during World War II. B-17s and B-29s had no reason or business being controlled by people focused on fighting the local, tactical war. Navy and Marine assets are mostly tactical for direct support of their operations, as they should be. Air Force Tactical Assets can and do provide direct support of Army and other operations as need by immediate request, but Army leaders should not be burdened with the maintenance of Air Fields at great distance form where the fighting is. That would be a unneeded nightmare... In hard times and lean times, there may be some fat to be cut away, but to suggest the Air Force should be cut up into pieces and doled out to the other services is pretty shallow-thinking and stupid - - Wandering and Wondering

content: quote: Originally posted by scooter_mech: The result is an “up or out” system that demands service members move up the ladder simply to stay in the military. Any soldier passed over for promotion twice must leave or retire. This is one segment of the editorial that makes sence. If a service member is competent at a certain level, they should be able to stay in at that level. The Navy is implementing a version of this, though the officer communities have had this for a loooong time. All Navy enlisted will be required to apply and complete for a limited number of reenlistment slots based on current manning needs in individual ratings (MOSs for you non-Sailors.) Any E-7 and above beyond retirement age will also be required to go before a continuation board every three years, which has the option of retiring them or keeping them in place.

content: What annoyed me about this article (of which I don't think I agreed with even one sentence), besides the many points already brought up, was that his numbers are terrible. 5% of "troops in Iraq"? How about "Troops in Support of OIF"? 'Cause when you calculate that the numbers more than double (12%, if I recall). He's using numbers that don't count an airman running flights daily from Baghdad to Ramstein (perhaps carrying wounded Marines to Landstuhl) as being in Iraq, as that airman is stationed in Germany. Sure, these guys are in theater nearly every day and puts his ass on the line, but he doesn't count purely on the Jarhead standard that only folks who sleep in Iraq for the whole tour count as being "at war". Same goes, I guess, for a fighter pilot flying CAS out of a base in Kuwait (though who knows... He might have cherry picked his numbers to include 5th Fleet but exclude USAF from EUCOM or CONUS who support OIF, which may or may not mean that Kuwait counts). National Service (let alone an actual draft) is obviously nonsensical for anyone who's studied the issue. I mean, is the problem that our unit morale or capability hasn't sunk to the level of draftee army's like the Russians? Why would anyone want to go back to having an Army made up of kids who don't want to be there and just didn't have daddies rich enough to pull the right strings? As for promotions... Do we really want to go back to the old way of doing things where veterans just stayed around as long as they wanted? Where guys like LTC Eisenhower have been sitting around waiting for the old guys to die or finally retire? (unless a war comes, in which case you quickly promote the people you should have promoted in the first place 4 or 5 grades) Do we want to return to the days where guys like U.S. Grant and W.T. Sherman left the Army as O-3's due to lack of opportunity for advancement (the Army being run at the time by a veteran of the War of 1812, who would be 74 years old before he retired)? What a terrible op-ed...
